Radovan Karadzic was arrested on Monday in Belgrade after nearly 13 years on the run.

One of the most wanted man in the world, Karadzic stands accused of genocide and crimes against humanity, for his part orchestrating the siege of Sarajevo and the Srebrenica Massacre during Bosnia's civil war.
After extradition to the Netherlands, he'll stand trial at the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia in Hague.
Karadzic adopted an alias, wore thick glasses and grew a bushy white beard to disguise his identity and worked openly in Belgrade as a doctor of alternative medicine.
His arrest brings Serbia one step closer to admission into the European Union.
In an op-ed for the Washington Post titled ""The Face of Evil,"" U.S.
Ambassador Richard Holbrooke described his meeting with Radovan Karadzic as NATO air strikes finally forced Bosnia Serbs to negotiate.

Ambassador Richard Holbrooke was the chief architect of the Dayton Peace Agreement that ended the Bosnian war.
He joins us now from our bureau in New York.
It's nice to have you in the program today, sir.
Good to be with you.
And you met Karadzic just once in 1995.
Can you describe that meeting for us?
We were on our fifth trip to Belgrade.
The war was at an intense level.
NATO bombers had been bombing the Bosnian Serbs for two weeks.
Three of our colleagues had been killed, Bob Frazier, Joe Kruzel and Nelson Drew had been killed on our first attempt to get into Sarajevo.
The city of Sarajevo was under siege and we came into Belgrade as we were bombing.
And I said to my colleagues that I thought Karadzic and Mladic might be brought into the negotiations by Milosevic this time around.
I should explain that we had deliberately cut Mladic and Karadzic out of the negotiations.
They'd negotiated with a lot of other people, including Jimmy Carter,but we just thought, bringing them in made it out more odious.
They were already indicted war criminals.
Slobodan Milosevic, the President of Serbia, would later be indicted.
He would later be indicted, and we wanted to force him to take responsibility for the war he was bankrolling and not legitimize these terrible, terrible men.
So we landed in Belgrade September 13th, 1995.
My negotiating team: General Wes Clark, Chris Hill - now the North Korean negotiator - myself, three or four other people.
Sure enough, Milosevic took us out to an old hunting lodge outside Belgrade and he said, Karadzic and Mladic are in a villa nearby.
Would you be willing to see him?
We had prepared for this, and we decided we would do it, once and only once, but we laid down some ground rules to Milosevic.
He would have to take personal responsibility for their conduct.
If they give us any crap, if they started lecturing us, we would walk out and the bombing would intensify.
And then Milosevic said, OK.
And then in the distance, as the fading light came over the countryside, we saw two men get out of their Mercedes and walked towards us across the field.

They were just unmistakable stocky, combat fatigue, Mladic walking as though he's walking through a mud field, and the taller man in a suit with that unmistakable shock of white hair, Radovan Karadzic.
They came to us.
I did not shake their hand.
Some of my colleagues did, others didn't.
It was their choice.
And we sat down to negotiate, and at the end of 13 hours and after a great deal of drama, we had agreed that the siege of Sarajevo would be lifted the next day.
And it was.
There was one, though, dramatic moment during those negotiations when you insisted that the siege of Sarajevo be lifted immediately.
Well, early on, Karadzic, of course, tested us, as we knew he would.
He started yelling and screaming that Serbs were victims, they were being humiliated.
He compared us to April 6th, 1941, the day that Hitler had bombed the Serbs in Belgrade, a famous day in Serbian history.
And I turned to Milosevic and I said, you know, you made an agreement with us that this wouldn't happen, and if it continues to happen, we're going to walk out and the bombing will intensify.
And then I turned to Karadzic.
Karadzic then said that he was a personal friend of Jimmy Carter's and he had Carter's phone number and he was going to go call Carter and get Carter involved.
So for the only time in 13 hours, I spoke to Karadzic directly and I said, listen, I worked for President Carter as Assistant Secretary of State.
I respect him, but we only have one president at a time and our president is Bill Clinton and that's the only person we work for.
And you go to call Carter, we're leaving and the bombing intensifies.
And Milosevic said something to him in Serbian and he sat down and the negotiations proceeded.
That day, I must tell you frankly, that day, the man who was much scarier was Ratko Mladic.
One had the sense that Karadzic was the intellectual architect of ethnic cleansing.
He really believed all the mythology about the Serbs, that he was a purveyor of - but the mass murderer, the hands-on murderer was Ratko Mladic.
And he, of course, is still at liberty somewhere in either Serbia or Bosnia-Herzegovina and...
Absolutely.
But I think - I think this is a big deal.
This was not - you know, your listeners need to really focus on something.
Thirteen years NATO failed to capture Karadzic.
He was captured by the Serb government after an election in which the pro-Western government, Boris Tadic's government, was elected.

I think that people of the world should know today that the hero of this story is Boris Tadic, a very brave man whose best friend, former Prime Minister Zoran Djindjic, was murdered after he had captured, arrested Milosevic and sent Milosevic to The Hague.
And I talked to Tadic a few months ago in a conference in Brussels, and he talked a great deal about Djindjic.
And he talked about the danger to his life, and he has taken a very important step.
It's going to help stabilize not only Serbia but Bosnia.
And you also pointed that this should boost the idea of war crimes tribunals even though Mladic still, and Karadzic, for 13 years, well, free from - unarrested after their indictment.
You're absolutely right.

You know, twelve, thirteen years is a long time, and there's no excuse for taking this long, particularly since many, many people were in on the secret of hiding him and are still in on the secret of hiding Mladic.
But what's important here is that even though it took this a period of time, he never was free to come out in public.
He had to do all this from the shadows.
He was always under pressure.

And other war criminals, and I'm thinking particularly of the president of Sudan, Mr. Bashir, who was indicted last week by the International Criminal Court, have got to understand after Karadzic's arrest that no matter how long it takes, once you're indicted, you are on the limb for the rest of your life.
And it isn't just a few Nazi hunters as it was in the days when the Israelis went to Argentina and snatched Eichmann.
Next time around, it will be an international arrest warrant as it was for Karadzic, as it is for Mladic and as it is now is for Bashir.
